articles.headline: Say-on-Pay Gets Support at Verizon
articles.snippet: A majority of Verizon shareholders voted for the say-on-pay proposal, the clearest sign yet of investor irritation over chief executive compensation.
articles.abstract: A majority of Verizon shareholders voted for the say-on-pay proposal, the clearest sign yet of investor irritation over chief executive compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: A proposal to give Verizon Communications’ shareholders a voice in its executive pay practices passed with 50.18 percent of the vote, the company said yesterday — the clearest sign yet of investor irritation over chief executive compensation.

articles.headline: Internet Giants Vie to Snap Up Web Ad Firms
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s $6 billion acquisition of aQuantive signaled its struggle to build an Internet ad business on its own.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s $6 billion acquisition of aQuantive signaled its struggle to build an Internet ad business on its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a good time to be an Internet advertising company.

articles.headline: New Routes and New Risk, as More Haitians Flee
articles.snippet: Haitian migrants, facing more U.S. patrols, are increasingly seeking alternative routes.
articles.abstract: Haitian migrants, facing more U.S. patrols, are increasingly seeking alternative routes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCIALES, Turks and Caicos, May 16 — There is no conceivable way to get from this island to Miami by bus. But the traffickers who ply Haiti’s northern coastline in search of those willing to risk their bleak lives for better ones abroad tell some tall tales to fill their rickety boats.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Mr. Horsepower Has an Electric Conversion
articles.snippet: Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman at General Motors, declared that its new hybrid-electric concept car may be among the most important vehicles that G.M. has ever developed.
articles.abstract: Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman at General Motors, declared that its new hybrid-electric concept car may be among the most important vehicles that G.M. has ever developed.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 18 — Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman at General Motors, has long been considered one of Detroit’s ultimate “car guys,” for whom no vehicle could be big enough, powerful enough or fast enough.

articles.headline: Houseguests Who Pay, and Pay Well
articles.snippet: A small but growing number of intrepid homeowners have figured out a way to make their prime locations pay.
articles.abstract: A small but growing number of intrepid homeowners have figured out a way to make their prime locations pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soaring real estate prices, taxes and the associated costs of living in a tourist destination can be an expensive endeavor. A small but growing number of intrepid homeowners, however, have figured out a way to make their prime locations pay.

articles.headline: A Return to the Land, for Fuel
articles.snippet: More companies in Hawaii are looking to its agricultural past to supply its energy-independent future.
articles.abstract: More companies in Hawaii are looking to its agricultural past to supply its energy-independent future.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHAINA, Hawaii — Here on the West Side of Maui, where lush mountainsides and the warm waters of the Alalakeiki Channel juxtapose increasingly crowded roadways and a spate of new luxury hotels, the push for renewable energy has found an unlikely advocate: the chief executive of one of the most aggressive developers on the island.

articles.headline: Contractor Deaths in Iraq Soar to Record
articles.snippet: At least 146 contract workers were killed in the first three months of 2007, revealing the increased risks they face as the military steps up its effort.
articles.abstract: At least 146 contract workers were killed in the first three months of 2007, revealing the increased risks they face as the military steps up its effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 18 — Casualties among private contractors in Iraq have soared to record levels this year, setting a pace that seems certain to turn 2007 into the bloodiest year yet for the civilians who work alongside the American military in the war zone, according to new government numbers.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and James Risen

articles.headline: Couple Learn the High Price of Easy Credit
articles.snippet: Two average earners in Michigan have found that their economic life depends on how well they shuffle their debt.
articles.abstract: Two average earners in Michigan have found that their economic life depends on how well they shuffle their debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: YPSILANTI, Mich. — On a recent evening, Christine Moellering, 40, sorted through the plastic laundry basket where she keeps the family bills, statements and coupons.

articles.headline: Destroying Dow Jones to Save It
articles.snippet: The Bancrofts’ neglect has hurt the company they all profess to love and made Rupert Murdoch’s bid possible.
articles.abstract: The Bancrofts’ neglect has hurt the company they all profess to love and made Rupert Murdoch’s bid possible.
articles.lead_paragraph: So let’s see. We’re now into week No. 3 of the business world’s favorite new soap opera, “Mr. Murdoch Lusts After Dow Jones.” And what a strange week it’s been.

articles.headline: Illegal Migrants Dissect Details of Senate Deal
articles.snippet: The immigration bill would change a system based primarily on family ties into one that favors skilled and educated workers.
articles.abstract: The immigration bill would change a system based primarily on family ties into one that favors skilled and educated workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON, May 19 — Under the shade of a mesquite tree here one morning this week, waiting for work that did not come, Elías Ramírez weighed the hurdles of what could be the biggest overhaul in immigration law in two decades.
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Julia Preston

articles.headline: A Wildcatter Pounces
articles.snippet: Joseph H. Bryant wants to hunt for oil in the Gulf of Mexico or offshore West Africa, challenging Big Oil in its own backyard.
articles.abstract: Joseph H. Bryant wants to hunt for oil in the Gulf of Mexico or offshore West Africa, challenging Big Oil in its own backyard.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON

articles.headline: Bilking the Elderly, With a Corporate Assist
articles.snippet: Large companies are selling vast databases of personal information to thieves, despite evidence their services are used for fraud.
articles.abstract: Large companies are selling vast databases of personal information to thieves, despite evidence their services are used for fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: The thieves operated from small offices in Toronto and hangar-size rooms in India. Every night, working from lists of names and phone numbers, they called World War II veterans, retired schoolteachers and thousands of other elderly Americans and posed as government and insurance workers updating their files.

articles.headline: As a Director, Clinton Moved Wal-Mart Board, but Only So Far
articles.snippet: In her six-year tenure as a director of Wal-Mart, Hillary Rodham Clinton was largely silent on the company’s anti-unionism.
articles.abstract: In her six-year tenure as a director of Wal-Mart, Hillary Rodham Clinton was largely silent on the company’s anti-unionism.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1986, Sam Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart, had a problem. He was under growing pressure from shareholders — and his wife, Helen — to appoint a woman to the company’s 15-member board of directors.

articles.headline: Africa’s Storied Colleges, Jammed and Crumbling
articles.snippet: Far from being a repository of the continent’s hopes for the future, Africa’s decrepit universities have become hotbeds of discontent.
articles.abstract: Far from being a repository of the continent’s hopes for the future, Africa’s decrepit universities have become hotbeds of discontent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal, May 19 — Thiany Dior usually rises before dawn, tiptoeing carefully among thin foam mats laid out on the floor as she leaves the cramped dormitory room she shares with half a dozen other women. It was built for two.

articles.headline: Who Controls Paradise?
articles.snippet: An ecological biosphere along Mexico’s western coast is a battleground for a blood feud.
articles.abstract: An ecological biosphere along Mexico’s western coast is a battleground for a blood feud.
articles.lead_paragraph: COSTA Alegre, Mexico

articles.headline: Just Saying No to Lowball Buyout Offers
articles.snippet: Some recent buyout bids  have been so inadequate that they seemed like gifts to the buyers, not the sellers.
articles.abstract: Some recent buyout bids  have been so inadequate that they seemed like gifts to the buyers, not the sellers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRACK open the Champagne.

articles.headline: U.S. Pays Pakistan to Fight Terror, but Patrols Ebb
articles.snippet: The Bush administration fears that cutting off cash or linking it to performance would further destabilize Pakistan’s president, according to some officials.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration fears that cutting off cash or linking it to performance would further destabilize Pakistan’s president, according to some officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 19 — The United States is continuing to make large payments of roughly $1 billion a year to Pakistan for what it calls reimbursements to the country’s military for conducting counterterrorism efforts along the border with Afghanistan, even though Pakistan’s president decided eight months ago to slash patrols through the area where Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters are most active.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and David Rohde

articles.headline: Emphasis Shifts for New Breed of Evangelicals
articles.snippet: The death of the Rev. Jerry Falwell highlighted the evangelical Christian movement’s recent evolution.
articles.abstract: The death of the Rev. Jerry Falwell highlighted the evangelical Christian movement’s recent evolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: The evangelical Christian movement, which has been pivotal in reshaping the country’s political landscape since the 1980s, has shifted in potentially momentous ways in recent years, broadening its agenda and exposing new fissures.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Hollywood Diet: Cutting Back on the Big Parties
articles.snippet: The industry’s splashy celebrations for big movie openings are bowing to the demands of cost-cutting.
articles.abstract: The industry’s splashy celebrations for big movie openings are bowing to the demands of cost-cutting.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, May 20 — The premiere of the Will Ferrell hit comedy “Blades of Glory” here in March could not have been more fabulous. Photographers crowded the red carpet at Grauman’s Chinese Theater, snapping pictures of celebrities like Ben Stiller and Brooke Shields. The ice skating stars Nancy Kerrigan and Dorothy Hamill mingled with eager fans.

articles.headline: Amid Dow Bid, Murdoch Family Comes Together
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch is using his family as a selling point as he woos the Bancrofts, who control Dow Jones & Company.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch is using his family as a selling point as he woos the Bancrofts, who control Dow Jones & Company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, a management conference for senior executives of the News Corporation in Pebble Beach, Calif., featured a range of attention-getting speakers, like Prime Minister Tony Blair, former President Bill Clinton and the rocker-humanitarian Bono.

articles.headline: Mortgage Fraud Is Up, but Not in Their Backyards
articles.snippet: Written off at first as bored housewives, three women who go by the All-Broad Fraud Squad are helping the F.B.I.
articles.abstract: Written off at first as bored housewives, three women who go by the All-Broad Fraud Squad are helping the F.B.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The three women call themselves the All-Broad Fraud Squad.

articles.headline: Electricity Crisis Hobbles an India Eager to Ascend
articles.snippet: Amid the hum of industry and a roaring economy, half of India’s people are left off the power grid.
articles.abstract: Amid the hum of industry and a roaring economy, half of India’s people are left off the power grid.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — This suburb south of New Delhi is where the fruits of India’s economic advance are on full display: sprawling malls, skyscrapers housing India’s acclaimed software companies, condominiums with names as fanciful as Nirvana Country.

articles.headline: Deal to Merge 2 Health Firms Aimed at Women
articles.snippet: Hologic Inc. announced it would acquire the Cytyc Corporation, and that they would together address all aspects of women’s health.
articles.abstract: Hologic Inc. announced it would acquire the Cytyc Corporation, and that they would together address all aspects of women’s health.
articles.lead_paragraph: Patrick J. Sullivan, the chief executive of the Cytyc Corporation, and Jack W. Cumming, the chief of Hologic Inc., like to joke about their companies splitting the geography of the female body. Hologic, a leader in breast cancer diagnostics, focuses on the top half, while Cytyc, a leader in diagnostics for cervical cancer, focuses on the bottom half.

articles.headline: Dozens Slain as Lebanese Army Fights Islamists
articles.snippet: The crisis was one of the most significant challenges to the army since the end of Lebanon’s bloody civil war.
articles.abstract: The crisis was one of the most significant challenges to the army since the end of Lebanon’s bloody civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 20 — Fierce clashes erupted between Lebanese Army soldiers and Islamic militants in the vicinity of a Palestinian refugee camp here on Sunday, leaving 22 Lebanese soldiers and 17 militants dead and dozens injured in one of the most significant challenges to the army since the end of Lebanon’s bloody civil war.
articles.byline: By Hassan M. Fattah and Nada Bakri

articles.headline: In Court Files, Hollywood’s Mr. Fix-It at Work
articles.snippet: Evidence so far in the case against Anthony Pellicano, “Detective to the Stars,” provides a vicarious tour through the dysfunctional heart of Hollywood.
articles.abstract: Evidence so far in the case against Anthony Pellicano, “Detective to the Stars,” provides a vicarious tour through the dysfunctional heart of Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, May 20 — Just hours after a raft of articles suggesting the impending collapse of his business hit the papers on April 11, 2002, Michael S. Ovitz did what Hollywood moguls had done for a generation: He called Anthony Pellicano.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner

articles.headline: Page Six Covers Itself, a Bit Painfully
articles.snippet: The New York Post’s alleged behavior raises serious implications for Rupert Murdoch’s plans to buy The Wall Street Journal.
articles.abstract: The New York Post’s alleged behavior raises serious implications for Rupert Murdoch’s plans to buy The Wall Street Journal.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you were a member of the Bancroft family in the midst of deciding whether to sell Dow Jones & Company to Rupert Murdoch, reading Friday’s New York Post might have made you choke on your bagel.

articles.headline: China to Buy a Stake in Blackstone
articles.snippet: It is China’s first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves beyond U.S. Treasury bills.
articles.abstract: It is China’s first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves beyond U.S. Treasury bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese government said yesterday that it would acquire a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, in the country’s first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves beyond United States Treasury bills and into commercial enterprise.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and David Barboza
